topic.name: NCLEX Practice
topic.description: Comprehensive NCLEX-RN practice questions covering all major client needs categories.
topic.detailedDescription: Authentic NCLEX-RN style practice questions designed following the NCLEX test plan and Nurseslabs methodology. This comprehensive question bank covers all Client Needs categories: Safe and Effective Care Environment (Management of Care, Safety and Infection Control), Health Promotion and Maintenance, Psychosocial Integrity, and Physiological Integrity (Basic Care and Comfort, Pharmacological Therapies, Reduction of Risk Potential, Physiological Adaptation). Each question includes detailed clinical scenarios, rationales for correct and incorrect answers, and mirrors the complexity and format of actual NCLEX exam questions. Perfect for final exam preparation and building test-taking confidence.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of post-operative clients requiring various interventions (Ms. Gomez) in a surgical recovery unit to administer post-op care protocols. Staffing is adequate with a mix of RNs, LPNs, and UAPs.

Which client care activity requires RN assessment and cannot be delegated?
options: Report changes in client condition to the charge nurse
Obtain vital signs on a stable post-op client
Apply non-sterile dressing to a chronic wound
Perform initial assessment on a newly admitted client
Document intake and output measurements
Feed a client with dysphagia and aspiration risk
questions.explanation: Routine vital signs on stable clients can be delegated to UAP.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of a 28-year-old recently started on clozapine (Mr. Wallace) in a mental health treatment facility. The client's current regimen includes atypical antipsychotic with weekly monitoring. The client develops fever, confusion, and muscle rigidity.

What assessment finding indicates a serious medication reaction?
options: White blood cell count of 2,000/mm³ with neutropenia
Mild hand tremor noted during medication administration
Teach client to report fever, sore throat, or flu-like symptoms immediately
Weight gain of 5 pounds over 2 months
Client reports feeling drowsy in the afternoon
Temperature 104°F (40°C) with severe muscle rigidity and altered mental status
questions.explanation: Agranulocytosis from clozapine requires immediate discontinuation to prevent sepsis.

questions.text:
The healthcare provider prescribes insulin infusion protocol for a 19-year-old with type 1 diabetes presenting with Kussmaul respirations (Mr. Al-Rashid) in an emergency department. Blood glucose is 520 mg/dL with pH 7.18 and positive ketones.

Which intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
Client reports extreme thirst
Initiate 0.9% normal saline bolus before starting insulin
Add potassium to IV fluids once level drops below 5.3 mEq/L
Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
questions.explanation: Closure of anion gap indicates resolution of ketoacidosis.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 68-year-old post-op day 3 from bowel resection (Mr. Lopez) in a surgical ICU. The client is receiving vasopressor support. Blood cultures are pending and lactate is 4.2 mmol/L.

Which assessment finding is the earliest indicator of septic shock?
options: Obtain blood cultures before initiating antibiotics
White blood cell count of 18,000/mm³
Lactate level trending down from 4.2 to 2.1 mmol/L
Urine output of 35 mL/hour after fluid bolus
Mean arterial pressure drops below 65 mm Hg despite fluids
Temperature of 101.8°F (38.8°C)
questions.explanation: Cultures must be drawn before antibiotics to identify the organism.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 45-year-old with myasthenia gravis presenting with severe weakness (Mr. Lopez) in an emergency department regarding edrophonium test consideration. The client has been taking pyridostigmine regularly but had a recent dosage increase.

Which assessment finding helps differentiate myasthenic from cholinergic crisis?
options: Fasciculations, increased salivation, and miosis with bradycardia
Prepare for intubation with declining respiratory effort
Muscle strength improves temporarily after edrophonium administration
Client reports feeling more fatigued than usual
Ptosis, diplopia, and dysphagia with normal pupil size
Administer atropine if cholinergic crisis is confirmed
questions.explanation: These cholinergic signs indicate excessive acetylcholinesterase inhibition.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mx. Santos, a 55-year-old with sudden aphasia and facial droop in a comprehensive stroke center who is receiving consideration for IV tPA. The family is uncertain about the exact time symptoms began.

Which assessment finding is an absolute contraindication to tPA?
options: NIH Stroke Scale score of 8
Blood pressure of 220/120 mm Hg that remains elevated despite treatment
Client takes daily aspirin 81 mg
Blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL
Onset time documented at 4.5 hours ago
Platelet count of 88,000/mm³
questions.explanation: Uncontrolled hypertension above 185/110 is a contraindication due to bleeding risk.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of magnesium sulfate infusion for a 26-year-old with postpartum hypertension (Mr. Lopez) in a high-risk obstetric unit, the nurse performs an assessment. Deep tendon reflexes and respiratory status are trending every 30 minutes.

What finding is most concerning while monitoring magnesium sulfate infusion?
options: Serum magnesium level of 9.0 mg/dL
Client reports feeling warm and flushed
Blood pressure decreases from 158/102 to 146/94
Client describes mild nausea
Magnesium level reported at 5.5 mg/dL
Respiratory rate that falls to 10 breaths per minute
questions.explanation: Levels above the therapeutic range of 4-7 mg/dL indicate toxicity.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Nguyen (multiple clients on a medical-surgical unit), is admitted to a busy med-surg floor during morning shift for routine care activities. The RN is working with two UAPs and has six assigned clients.

Which task can the RN safely delegate to unlicensed assistive personnel?
options: Feed a client with dysphagia and aspiration risk
Obtain vital signs on a stable post-op client
Apply non-sterile dressing to a chronic wound
Document intake and output measurements
Perform initial assessment on a newly admitted client
Report changes in client condition to the charge nurse
questions.explanation: Requires nursing judgment and swallowing assessment; cannot be delegated.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a cardiac ICU, the nurse checks on Mx. Jordan, a 66-year-old male two hours post anterior myocardial infarction, who is receiving lidocaine loading dose followed by 2 mg/min maintenance. Ventricular ectopy has persisted despite electrolyte correction.

Which cue needs the fastest intervention while titrating ventricular ectopy and conduction times?
options: Oxygen saturation trending 96% on 2 L/min nasal cannula
A progressive drop in arterial blood pressure accompanied by bradycardia
Client reporting localized IV site warmth
Occasional premature ventricular contractions that match baseline frequency
Complaint of mild metallic taste
Serum potassium that dropped from 4.2 to 3.1 mEq/L
questions.explanation: Hypotension with bradycardia suggests hemodynamic compromise from the infusion.

questions.text:
In a mental health treatment facility, the nurse is evaluating a 28-year-old recently started on clozapine (Dr. Bennett) who is receiving atypical antipsychotic with weekly monitoring. The client develops fever, confusion, and muscle rigidity.

Which adverse effect requires immediate intervention?
options: Mild hand tremor noted during medication administration
Temperature 104°F (40°C) with severe muscle rigidity and altered mental status
Client reports feeling drowsy in the afternoon
Weight gain of 5 pounds over 2 months
Involuntary tongue protrusion and facial grimacing
White blood cell count of 2,000/mm³ with neutropenia
questions.explanation: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate discontinuation.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Ms. Harper, a 4-year-old with asthma exacerbation in an emergency department, who is currently on nebulized beta-agonists and steroids. The child has been receiving back-to-back treatments.

What observation indicates the child is tiring?
options: Suprasternal and intercostal retractions that suddenly diminish
Capillary refill under 2 seconds
Mild inspiratory wheezing improving after treatment
Respiratory rate of 34/min with even chest rise
Altered mental status with lethargy
Heart rate 160/min while crying
questions.explanation: A sudden drop in retractions signals diaphragmatic fatigue and impending failure.

questions.text:
The healthcare provider prescribes IV furosemide bolus every 4 hours for a 74-year-old with acute decompensated heart failure (Dr. Bennett) in a cardiac step-down unit. The client has lost 1.5 kg since admission and labs are pending.

Which assessment finding shows the diuretic is causing harm?
options: Lung sounds improved from coarse crackles to fine bibasilar crackles
Client reports ringing in the ears after the push dose
Sodium level of 134 mEq/L
Net negative output of 1 liter over 8 hours
Client requests assistance to the bathroom every two hours
Serum creatinine rising from 1.0 to 1.8 mg/dL overnight
questions.explanation: Tinnitus is a sign of loop diuretic ototoxicity and requires intervention.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for multiple clients on a medical-surgical unit (Mr. Yang) in a busy med-surg floor during morning shift regarding routine care activities. The RN is working with two UAPs and has six assigned clients.

Which task can the RN safely delegate to unlicensed assistive personnel?
options: Report changes in client condition to the charge nurse
Apply non-sterile dressing to a chronic wound
Document intake and output measurements
Perform initial assessment on a newly admitted client
Assist a client with ambulation using a gait belt
Feed a client with dysphagia and aspiration risk
questions.explanation: Initial assessments require RN clinical judgment and cannot be delegated.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of a 45-year-old with a hemorrhagic stroke (Mr. Al-Rashid) in a neuro step-down unit. The client's current regimen includes hyperosmolar therapy. The nurse performs hourly cranial nerve checks.

Which assessment change requires immediate provider notification?
options: Widening pulse pressure with bradycardia
Client reports headache rated 4/10
Unequal pupils with sluggish reaction to light
ICP waveform showing regular P1>P2 pattern
Temperature of 99.2 F (37.3 C)
Urine output of 55 mL/hour
questions.explanation: Cushing response indicates rising ICP and brainstem compression.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Mr. Haddad, a 28-year-old 30 minutes post-vaginal delivery in a labor and delivery unit, indicate active treatment with fundal massage and oxytocin infusion. The client delivered a 9-pound infant after prolonged labor.

What intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Fundus firm at umbilicus level
Fundus boggy and displaced to the right above the umbilicus
Lochia rubra with small clots
Perform vigorous fundal massage while supporting the lower uterine segment
Rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, and restlessness
Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
questions.explanation: Indicates uterine atony requiring immediate massage and bladder emptying.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Mr. Al-Rashid, a 72-year-old with home oxygen presenting with worsening cough in an emergency department, who is currently on antibiotics for suspected bacterial superinfection. Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air.

What assessment finding indicates the client's status is worsening?
options: Maintain oxygen saturation between 88-92% using low-flow oxygen
Bilateral expiratory wheezes throughout lung fields
Decreasing level of consciousness with CO2 retention
Increase oxygen to maintain saturation above 95%
Respiratory rate of 24/min with prolonged expiration
Administer methylprednisolone to reduce airway inflammation
questions.explanation: COPD patients rely on hypoxic drive; excessive oxygen can suppress respirations.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Mr. Park, a 32-year-old post-cesarean section for placenta previa in a postpartum recovery area, indicate active treatment with blood transfusion protocol. Estimated blood loss was 1200 mL and the client appears pale and dizzy.

What intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Perform vigorous fundal massage while supporting the lower uterine segment
Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
Blood loss exceeding 500 mL vaginal or 1000 mL cesarean
Lochia rubra with small clots
Rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, and restlessness
Fundus firm at umbilicus level
questions.explanation: Stimulates uterine contraction to control bleeding from placental site.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor (Ms. Romero) is being treated in a labor and delivery suite with continuous external fetal monitoring. Contractions are occurring every 3 minutes lasting 60 seconds.

Which fetal heart rate pattern requires immediate intervention?
options: Prolonged deceleration lasting 4 minutes with baseline below 90 bpm
Moderate variability with accelerations during fetal movement
Recurrent late decelerations with minimal variability
Baseline fetal heart rate of 145 bpm
Absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations
Early decelerations that mirror contraction pattern
questions.explanation: Prolonged bradycardia suggests cord compression or placental abruption.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 70-year-old recovering from respiratory failure (Ms. Yamamoto) in a critical care step-down unit. The client is on spontaneous breathing trial. The trial has been ongoing for 20 minutes.

Which assessment supports successful extubation?
options: Client reports feeling anxious during the trial
Chest X-ray showing bibasilar atelectasis
Heart rate increase from 78 to 88/min during trial
Rapid shallow breathing index below 105 with PEEP of 5 cm H2O
Strong cough with copious secretions managed independently
PaO2/FiO2 ratio greater than 200
questions.explanation: Low RSBI indicates adequate respiratory muscle strength for weaning.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 68-year-old recovering from a mechanical mitral valve replacement (Mr. Brown) in a cardiac step-down unit. The client is prescribed warfarin with bridge therapy. The client takes herbal supplements at home and prepares leafy greens daily.

Which instruction must the nurse emphasize before discharge?
options: Take the medication at bedtime to avoid daytime drowsiness
Report any bruising, nosebleeds, or black stools to the provider immediately
Keep vitamin K intake consistent rather than eliminating leafy vegetables
Keep a blood pressure log every morning
Use ibuprofen for headaches instead of acetaminophen
Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
questions.explanation: Unusual bleeding can signal excessive anticoagulation and must be reported.

questions.text:
In a surgical recovery unit, the nurse is evaluating a 58-year-old receiving IV morphine for post-operative pain (Ms. Rodriguez) who is receiving PCA morphine with basal rate. The client has obstructive sleep apnea and received a bolus dose 30 minutes ago.

Which assessment finding requires withholding the opioid dose?
options: Client reports pain level of 6/10
Pinpoint pupils with decreased level of consciousness
Keep naloxone readily available at the bedside
Client sleeping but easily arousable with normal respirations
Blood pressure slightly decreased from baseline
Respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute with sedation score of 3
questions.explanation: Classic signs of opioid overdose requiring naloxone administration.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 58-year-old receiving IV morphine for post-operative pain (Ms. Romero) in a surgical recovery unit. The client is receiving PCA morphine with basal rate. The client has obstructive sleep apnea and received a bolus dose 30 minutes ago.

Which assessment finding requires withholding the opioid dose?
options: Client reports pain level of 6/10
Respiratory rate of 8 breaths per minute with sedation score of 3
Client sleeping but easily arousable with normal respirations
Blood pressure slightly decreased from baseline
Pinpoint pupils with decreased level of consciousness
Inability to arouse the client with verbal or tactile stimulation
questions.explanation: Bradypnea with deep sedation indicates dangerous respiratory depression.

questions.text:
The healthcare provider prescribes informed consent process for a 68-year-old scheduled for cardiac catheterization in one hour (Mr. Singh) in a pre-procedure area. The client signed the consent form but asks basic questions about the procedure.

Which action protects the client's rights?
options: Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Consent signed while client was under influence of sedative medications
Client appears nervous about the procedure
Client states, 'I don't want the procedure, but my family insists'
Family members are present and supportive
questions.explanation: Nurse advocates by ensuring informed consent requirements are met.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 38-year-old with MG admitted for pneumonia (Mr. Haddad) in a medical ICU. The client is prescribed plasma exchange. Bulbar symptoms are worsening with dysphagia and weak cough.

What intervention should the nurse anticipate first?
options: Prepare for intubation with declining respiratory effort
Muscle strength improves temporarily after edrophonium administration
Client reports feeling more fatigued than usual
Recent antibiotic therapy with fluoroquinolone
Fasciculations, increased salivation, and miosis with bradycardia
Administer atropine if cholinergic crisis is confirmed
questions.explanation: Both crisis types can cause respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old with sickle cell disease reporting severe chest and back pain (Mr. Rossi) is being treated in an emergency department with IV opioid analgesia and hydration. Pain started 6 hours ago and rates it 9/10.

What assessment finding indicates the crisis is worsening?
options: Administer IV fluids at 1.5 times maintenance to promote hemodilution
Hemoglobin of 8 g/dL
Initiate aggressive pain management with opioids around-the-clock
New onset fever, chest pain, and decreased oxygen saturation
Client requests heating pad for painful joints
Encourage bed rest to conserve energy
questions.explanation: Hydration reduces blood viscosity and improves microcirculation.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Mr. Wallace, a 68-year-old scheduled for cardiac catheterization in one hour in a pre-procedure area, who is currently on informed consent process. The client signed the consent form but asks basic questions about the procedure.

Which action protects the client's rights?
options: Family members are present and supportive
Consent signed while client was under influence of sedative medications
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Client appears nervous about the procedure
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Client states, 'I don't want the procedure, but my family insists'
questions.explanation: Patient must be competent and alert to provide valid consent.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a labor and delivery unit, the nurse checks on Mr. Alvarez, a 28-year-old 30 minutes post-vaginal delivery, who is receiving fundal massage and oxytocin infusion. The client delivered a 9-pound infant after prolonged labor.

What intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Fundus firm at umbilicus level
Fundus boggy and displaced to the right above the umbilicus
Blood loss exceeding 500 mL vaginal or 1000 mL cesarean
Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
Lochia rubra with small clots
Rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, and restlessness
questions.explanation: Indicates uterine atony requiring immediate massage and bladder emptying.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Gomez (a 3-year-old with suspected measles), asks the nurse in a pediatric emergency department about their supportive care. The child has fever, cough, and characteristic rash.

Which type of isolation precaution is required for this client?
options: Standard precautions alone are adequate
Cohort the client with another TB patient
Wear an N95 respirator before entering the room
Place the client in a negative pressure isolation room
Wear a surgical mask, which is sufficient for TB
Keep the door closed at all times
questions.explanation: N95 filters particles <5 microns necessary for airborne pathogens.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 58-year-old with septic shock on vasopressor support (Mr. Ibrahim) in a medical ICU. The client is receiving norepinephrine infusion. Creatinine rose from 1.1 to 2.4 mg/dL in 24 hours.

Which laboratory finding is the earliest indicator of acute kidney injury?
options: Urine output less than 0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6 consecutive hours
BUN/creatinine ratio of 15:1
Potassium level of 6.2 mEq/L with peaked T waves on ECG
Serum creatinine increase of 0.3 mg/dL or more within 48 hours
Client reports nausea and fatigue
Urine specific gravity of 1.010
questions.explanation: Oliguria is a defining characteristic of AKI.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in an emergency department, the nurse checks on Ms. Romero, a 62-year-old presenting with left-sided weakness and slurred speech, who is receiving alteplase infusion. Symptom onset was 90 minutes ago and CT shows no hemorrhage.

Which client statement would exclude them from receiving tPA?
options: NIH Stroke Scale score of 8
Blood pressure of 220/120 mm Hg that remains elevated despite treatment
Platelet count of 88,000/mm³
Blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL
Onset time documented at 4.5 hours ago
Client takes daily aspirin 81 mg
questions.explanation: Uncontrolled hypertension above 185/110 is a contraindication due to bleeding risk.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 72-year-old with atrial fibrillation and a healed peptic ulcer (Ms. Harper) in an outpatient anticoagulation clinic regarding warfarin 5 mg daily. The INR today is 2.4 and the client is eager to resume normal activities.

What teaching point has the highest priority while reinforcing bleeding precautions?
options: Use ibuprofen for headaches instead of acetaminophen
Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
Inform every healthcare provider and dentist about warfarin therapy
Take the medication at bedtime to avoid daytime drowsiness
Keep a blood pressure log every morning
Report any bruising, nosebleeds, or black stools to the provider immediately
questions.explanation: All clinicians must know about anticoagulation before procedures or prescriptions.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Ms. Romero, a 28-year-old on hour 16 of burn resuscitation in a regional burn center, who is currently on lactated Ringer's infusion. Urine output has been trending 25 mL/hour for the past 3 hours.

What is the priority intervention during the emergent phase?
options: Hematocrit elevation to 52%
Administer half of calculated 24-hour fluid volume in the first 8 hours
Urine output consistently below 30 mL/hour despite aggressive fluids
Client reports severe pain at burn sites
Urine output maintained at 30-50 mL/hour or 0.5 mL/kg/hour
Blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg
questions.explanation: Parkland formula requires frontloading fluids in the first 8 hours post-burn.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 45-year-old on day 2 of chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma (Ms. Silva) in a cancer center. The client is on rasburicase administration. Urine output has been adequate at 150 mL/hour.

Which client is at highest risk for this complication?
options: Urine pH of 6.5
Cardiac monitor showing peaked T waves and widened QRS
Maintain urine output of at least 2-3 L/day with IV hydration
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
questions.explanation: Life-threatening hyperkalemia requires emergent treatment.

questions.text:
While assessing a 28-year-old 30 minutes post-vaginal delivery (Mr. Okoye) in a labor and delivery unit, the nurse notes the client is receiving fundal massage and oxytocin infusion. The client delivered a 9-pound infant after prolonged labor.

What intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
Lochia rubra with small clots
Fundus firm at umbilicus level
Perform vigorous fundal massage while supporting the lower uterine segment
Rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, and restlessness
Fundus boggy and displaced to the right above the umbilicus
questions.explanation: Stimulates uterine contraction to control bleeding from placental site.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Ms. Silva, a 68-year-old scheduled for cardiac catheterization in one hour in a pre-procedure area, indicate active treatment with informed consent process. The client signed the consent form but asks basic questions about the procedure.

Which action protects the client's rights?
options: Client appears nervous about the procedure
Consent signed while client was under influence of sedative medications
Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Family members are present and supportive
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
questions.explanation: Patient must be competent and alert to provide valid consent.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 45-year-old with limited English proficiency signing surgical consent (Mr. Haddad) in a surgical holding area. The client is on interpreter services. The consent form is in English and no interpreter was present.

Which situation requires the nurse to intervene before the procedure?
options: Family members are present and supportive
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Client states, 'I don't want the procedure, but my family insists'
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Client appears nervous about the procedure
questions.explanation: Nurse advocates by ensuring informed consent requirements are met.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of IV opioid analgesia and hydration for a 28-year-old with sickle cell disease reporting severe chest and back pain (Ms. Patel) in an emergency department, the nurse performs an assessment. Pain started 6 hours ago and rates it 9/10.

Which intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Hemoglobin of 8 g/dL
New onset fever, chest pain, and decreased oxygen saturation
Encourage bed rest to conserve energy
Initiate aggressive pain management with opioids around-the-clock
Client requests heating pad for painful joints
Administer IV fluids at 1.5 times maintenance to promote hemodilution
questions.explanation: Triad of acute chest syndrome, a life-threatening complication.

questions.text:
In an outpatient clinic, the nurse is evaluating a 42-year-old stung by a bee in the hospital garden (Ms. Nguyen) who is receiving emergency anaphylaxis protocol. The client has known bee allergy and appears anxious with flushed skin.

Which intervention should the nurse implement immediately?
options: Administer diphenhydramine 50 mg IV after epinephrine
Urticaria spreading across the chest and arms
Blood pressure 82/50 mm Hg with rapid, weak pulse
Administer epinephrine 0.3-0.5 mg IM into the lateral thigh immediately
Stop the infusion and maintain IV access with normal saline
Client reports feeling anxious and dizzy
questions.explanation: Distributive shock from massive vasodilation requires immediate treatment.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 72-year-old with atrial fibrillation and a healed peptic ulcer (Ms. Silva) in an outpatient anticoagulation clinic. Current therapy includes warfarin 5 mg daily. The INR today is 2.4 and the client is eager to resume normal activities.

What teaching point has the highest priority while reinforcing bleeding precautions?
options: Keep a blood pressure log every morning
Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
Use ibuprofen for headaches instead of acetaminophen
Report any bruising, nosebleeds, or black stools to the provider immediately
Inform every healthcare provider and dentist about warfarin therapy
Take the medication at bedtime to avoid daytime drowsiness
questions.explanation: Unusual bleeding can signal excessive anticoagulation and must be reported.

questions.text:
The healthcare provider prescribes supportive care for a 3-year-old with suspected measles (Ms. Silva) in a pediatric emergency department. The child has fever, cough, and characteristic rash.

Which infection requires airborne precautions?
options: Keep the door closed at all times
Standard precautions alone are adequate
Cohort the client with another TB patient
Wear a surgical mask, which is sufficient for TB
Place the client in a negative pressure isolation room
Wear an N95 respirator before entering the room
questions.explanation: Essential for maintaining negative pressure in airborne isolation.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old with a traumatic brain injury (Dr. Bennett) is being treated in a neuro ICU with ventricular drain with ICP monitoring. Sedation has been lightened for a neuro exam.

Which assessment change requires immediate provider notification?
options: Urine output of 55 mL/hour
ICP waveform showing regular P1>P2 pattern
A sudden decrease in level of consciousness
Decorticate posturing noted during stimulation
Temperature of 99.2 F (37.3 C)
Client reports headache rated 4/10
questions.explanation: LOC decline is the earliest and most important sign of worsening ICP.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of a 68-year-old scheduled for cardiac catheterization in one hour (Ms. Yamamoto) in a pre-procedure area. The client's current regimen includes informed consent process. The client signed the consent form but asks basic questions about the procedure.

Which action protects the client's rights?
options: Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Client states, 'I don't want the procedure, but my family insists'
Family members are present and supportive
Client appears nervous about the procedure
questions.explanation: Indicates lack of understanding; consent may not be truly informed.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old with acute MI presenting with hypotension and pulmonary edema (Mx. Santos) is being treated in a cardiac catheterization lab with inotropic support and mechanical circulatory support consideration. The client has cold, clammy skin with decreased urine output.

Which hemodynamic finding confirms cardiogenic shock?
options: Cardiac index below 2.2 L/min/m² with elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
Prepare for intra-aortic balloon pump or mechanical circulatory support
Administer morphine for chest pain and anxiety
Lactate level elevated at 3.2 mmol/L
Blood pressure 88/60 mm Hg
Initiate dobutamine to improve contractility and cardiac output
questions.explanation: Defines cardiogenic shock: inadequate cardiac output despite adequate preload.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 32-year-old presenting to the ED with a wrist fracture (Mr. Lopez) in an emergency department to administer injury treatment and safety assessment. The client has multiple bruises in various stages of healing and partner refuses to leave the room.

Which assessment finding raises concern for intimate partner violence?
options: Document findings objectively using body maps and photographs with consent
Delay in seeking treatment after injury
Client denies abuse when partner is present
Partner appears concerned and attentive
Interview the client privately without the partner present
Provide information about domestic violence resources and safety planning
questions.explanation: Thorough documentation supports legal proceedings and continuity of care.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 45-year-old with myasthenia gravis presenting with severe weakness (Mr. Lopez) in an emergency department regarding edrophonium test consideration. The client has been taking pyridostigmine regularly but had a recent dosage increase.

What intervention should the nurse anticipate first?
options: Muscle strength improves temporarily after edrophonium administration
Recent antibiotic therapy with fluoroquinolone
Ptosis, diplopia, and dysphagia with normal pupil size
Client reports feeling more fatigued than usual
Administer atropine if cholinergic crisis is confirmed
Fasciculations, increased salivation, and miosis with bradycardia
questions.explanation: Certain antibiotics can precipitate myasthenic crisis.

questions.text:
In an orthopedic unit, the nurse is evaluating a 23-year-old with a tibial fracture and new cast applied 4 hours ago (Mr. Kaur) who is receiving elevation and ice application. The client reports increasing pain despite opioid administration.

Which client complaint warrants urgent evaluation?
options: Affected limb is cool to touch
Pain that is disproportionate to injury and unrelieved by opioids
Client reports the cast feels tight
Paresthesia and decreased sensation in the affected extremity
Absence of pulses in the affected extremity
Bivalve the cast immediately and remove all constrictive dressings
questions.explanation: Progressive, severe pain is the earliest and most reliable sign.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mr. Al-Rashid, a 9-month-old with bronchiolitis in a pediatric step-down unit who is receiving high-flow nasal cannula oxygen. Parents are at the bedside during evening assessments.

Which cue suggests impending respiratory failure?
options: Heart rate 160/min while crying
Pulse oximetry falling to 88% despite oxygen support
Mild inspiratory wheezing improving after treatment
Respiratory rate of 34/min with even chest rise
Altered mental status with lethargy
Capillary refill under 2 seconds
questions.explanation: Persistent hypoxemia warrants escalation.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of rasburicase administration for a 45-year-old on day 2 of chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma (Mr. Carter) in a cancer center, the nurse performs an assessment. Urine output has been adequate at 150 mL/hour.

What intervention should the nurse prioritize?
options: Maintain urine output of at least 2-3 L/day with IV hydration
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
Urine pH of 6.5
Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
Potassium 6.8 mEq/L, phosphorus 7.2 mg/dL, calcium 6.9 mg/dL
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
questions.explanation: High urine flow prevents crystal formation and flushes metabolites.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Mr. Carter, a 32-year-old post-cesarean section for placenta previa in a postpartum recovery area, indicate active treatment with blood transfusion protocol. Estimated blood loss was 1200 mL and the client appears pale and dizzy.

Which factor places this client at highest risk?
options: Perform vigorous fundal massage while supporting the lower uterine segment
Blood loss exceeding 500 mL vaginal or 1000 mL cesarean
Fundus firm at umbilicus level
Lochia rubra with small clots
Rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, and restlessness
Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
questions.explanation: Stimulates uterine contraction to control bleeding from placental site.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Mr. Singh, a 19-year-old with type 1 diabetes presenting with Kussmaul respirations in an emergency department, indicate active treatment with insulin infusion protocol. Blood glucose is 520 mg/dL with pH 7.18 and positive ketones.

Which intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
New onset headache, bradycardia, and altered mental status
Initiate 0.9% normal saline bolus before starting insulin
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
Client reports extreme thirst
questions.explanation: Closure of anion gap indicates resolution of ketoacidosis.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 33-year-old scheduled for elective abdominal surgery (Mr. Brown) in a preoperative holding area to administer a short peripheral catheter. The forearm is very hairy and the client reacts to many adhesives.

What is the safest way to manage excess hair before starting the IV?
options: Shave the area with a razor just before insertion
Use a single-patient clipper to trim hair down to stubble
Use a sterile scalpel to remove hair close to the skin
Leave the hair intact to avoid upsetting the client
Apply depilatory cream and wipe it off after three minutes
Smooth the hair with a water-based lubricant before taping
questions.explanation: Clipping removes hair without causing micro-abrasions that raise infection risk.

questions.text:
A client, Mx. Jordan (a 32-year-old primigravida with epidural analgesia), asks the nurse in a birthing center about their internal fetal scalp electrode monitoring. The client is fully dilated and beginning to push.

Which finding on the monitor strip indicates fetal compromise?
options: Early decelerations that mirror contraction pattern
Recurrent late decelerations with minimal variability
Moderate variability with accelerations during fetal movement
Prolonged deceleration lasting 4 minutes with baseline below 90 bpm
Baseline fetal heart rate of 145 bpm
Absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations
questions.explanation: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 24-year-old admitted for DKA now on hour 8 of treatment (Ms. Nguyen) in a medical ICU regarding IV regular insulin and potassium replacement. Glucose has dropped to 180 mg/dL but pH remains 7.28.

What laboratory finding indicates DKA is resolving?
options: Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
Client reports extreme thirst
Initiate 0.9% normal saline bolus before starting insulin
New onset headache, bradycardia, and altered mental status
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
questions.explanation: Fluid resuscitation must precede insulin to prevent vascular collapse.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mr. Park, a 52-year-old beginning chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia in an oncology unit who is receiving aggressive IV hydration and allopurinol. Pre-treatment labs show high white blood cell count with large tumor burden.

Which laboratory finding is most concerning for tumor lysis syndrome?
options: Potassium 6.8 mEq/L, phosphorus 7.2 mg/dL, calcium 6.9 mg/dL
Cardiac monitor showing peaked T waves and widened QRS
Urine pH of 6.5
Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
questions.explanation: The classic TLS triad: hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of elevation and ice application for a 23-year-old with a tibial fracture and new cast applied 4 hours ago (Ms. Gomez) in an orthopedic unit, the nurse performs an assessment. The client reports increasing pain despite opioid administration.

What intervention requires immediate action?
options: Pain that is disproportionate to injury and unrelieved by opioids
Bivalve the cast immediately and remove all constrictive dressings
Affected limb is cool to touch
Client reports the cast feels tight
Paresthesia and decreased sensation in the affected extremity
Absence of pulses in the affected extremity
questions.explanation: Progressive, severe pain is the earliest and most reliable sign.

questions.text:
The nurse responds to a call light for a 23-year-old with a tibial fracture and new cast applied 4 hours ago (Ms. Harper) in an orthopedic unit. The client is on elevation and ice application. The client reports increasing pain despite opioid administration.

What intervention requires immediate action?
options: Pain with passive stretching of muscles in the affected compartment
Affected limb is cool to touch
Absence of pulses in the affected extremity
Client reports the cast feels tight
Pain that is disproportionate to injury and unrelieved by opioids
Bivalve the cast immediately and remove all constrictive dressings
questions.explanation: Passive stretch pain indicates ischemia and impending necrosis.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 45-year-old with limited English proficiency signing surgical consent (Mr. Kaur) in a surgical holding area to administer interpreter services. The consent form is in English and no interpreter was present.

What indicates the consent is not valid?
options: Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Consent signed while client was under influence of sedative medications
Family members are present and supportive
Client appears nervous about the procedure
questions.explanation: Indicates lack of understanding; consent may not be truly informed.

questions.text:
While assessing a 19-year-old with type 1 diabetes presenting with Kussmaul respirations (Mr. Rossi) in an emergency department, the nurse notes the client is receiving insulin infusion protocol. Blood glucose is 520 mg/dL with pH 7.18 and positive ketones.

Which complication requires immediate recognition during treatment?
options: New onset headache, bradycardia, and altered mental status
Add potassium to IV fluids once level drops below 5.3 mEq/L
Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
Client reports extreme thirst
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
questions.explanation: Signs of cerebral edema, a life-threatening complication of DKA treatment.

questions.text:
The healthcare provider prescribes continuous external fetal monitoring for a 28-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor (Mr. Al-Rashid) in a labor and delivery suite. Contractions are occurring every 3 minutes lasting 60 seconds.

Which finding on the monitor strip indicates fetal compromise?
options: Prolonged deceleration lasting 4 minutes with baseline below 90 bpm
Absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations
Recurrent late decelerations with minimal variability
Moderate variability with accelerations during fetal movement
Early decelerations that mirror contraction pattern
Baseline fetal heart rate of 145 bpm
questions.explanation: Prolonged bradycardia suggests cord compression or placental abruption.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of continuous bumetanide infusion for a 60-year-old with pulmonary edema (Mr. Carter) in an ICU, the nurse performs an assessment. Strict intake and output and telemetry monitoring are in place.

What cue should the nurse address first during high-dose diuresis?
options: Sodium level of 134 mEq/L
Client requests assistance to the bathroom every two hours
Client reports ringing in the ears after the push dose
Lung sounds improved from coarse crackles to fine bibasilar crackles
Serum creatinine rising from 1.0 to 1.8 mg/dL overnight
Net negative output of 1 liter over 8 hours
questions.explanation: Tinnitus is a sign of loop diuretic ototoxicity and requires intervention.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 62-year-old after knee arthroplasty (Mr. Lopez) in an orthopedic unit to administer a negative pressure dressing. Family members are assisting with repositioning.

Which observation requires intervention to maintain asepsis?
options: Pack the incision with cotton balls soaked in peroxide
Change the dressing only if it becomes fully saturated
Massage around the incision to promote circulation
Perform hand hygiene and don clean gloves before touching the incision
Teach the client to report increasing drainage volume or odor
Keep the incision covered when around pets or crowded areas
questions.explanation: Hand hygiene remains the highest-leverage intervention to prevent infection.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of medication reconciliation for a 76-year-old with newly prescribed medications after hospitalization (Ms. Wilson) in a transitional care clinic, the nurse performs an assessment. Home medications include anticoagulants, NSAIDs, and antiplatelets.

What adverse effect is most concerning with this medication combination?
options: New cognitive impairment with urinary retention and dry mouth
Client sees multiple specialists
Client uses a weekly pill organizer
Concurrent use of warfarin, aspirin, and ibuprofen
Family helps manage medication administration
Diphenhydramine prescribed for sleep in an 82-year-old
questions.explanation: Classic anticholinergic toxicity syndrome requiring medication review.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Ms. Mbatha, an 80-year-old taking 12 daily medications including anticholinergics in a geriatric clinic, indicate active treatment with comprehensive medication review. The client reports new-onset confusion and recent falls.

Which medication should the nurse question for this elderly client?
options: Concurrent use of warfarin, aspirin, and ibuprofen
Family helps manage medication administration
Diphenhydramine prescribed for sleep in an 82-year-old
Client sees multiple specialists
New cognitive impairment with urinary retention and dry mouth
Client uses a weekly pill organizer
questions.explanation: Triple antithrombotic therapy dramatically increases bleeding risk.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in an operating room is discussing the care plan for Mr. Rossi, a 32-year-old undergoing general anesthesia for orthopedic surgery, who is receiving inhalational anesthetic agents. The client suddenly develops tachycardia and rigidity during the procedure.

Which medication should the nurse prepare to administer?
options: Rapidly rising end-tidal CO2 with unexplained tachycardia and rigidity
Family history of unexplained perioperative death
Initiate active cooling measures
Temperature spiking to 105°F (40.6°C) or higher
Prepare dantrolene sodium for immediate IV administration
Obtain arterial blood gas to assess metabolic acidosis
questions.explanation: Early signs of MH hypermetabolic state requiring immediate action.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Silva (a 68-year-old post-op day 3 from bowel resection), asks the nurse in a surgical ICU about their vasopressor support. Blood cultures are pending and lactate is 4.2 mmol/L.

Which assessment finding is the earliest indicator of septic shock?
options: Administer 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus within the first 3 hours
White blood cell count of 18,000/mm³
Temperature of 101.8°F (38.8°C)
Mean arterial pressure drops below 65 mm Hg despite fluids
Obtain blood cultures before initiating antibiotics
Urine output of 35 mL/hour after fluid bolus
questions.explanation: Early aggressive fluid resuscitation is a core sepsis bundle element.

questions.text:
A client, Ms. Nguyen (a 30-year-old post-op day 1 from forearm fracture repair), asks the nurse in a surgical unit about their compression dressing. Fingers appear pale with decreased capillary refill.

What intervention requires immediate action?
options: Bivalve the cast immediately and remove all constrictive dressings
Client reports the cast feels tight
Affected limb is cool to touch
Absence of pulses in the affected extremity
Paresthesia and decreased sensation in the affected extremity
Pain with passive stretching of muscles in the affected compartment
questions.explanation: Immediate pressure relief can prevent permanent damage.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a telemetry step-down unit, the nurse checks on Ms. Patel, a 58-year-old female with dilated cardiomyopathy, who is receiving continuous lidocaine infusion targeting ventricular trigeminy. The nurse is reviewing the rhythm strip during bedside rounds.

What assessment data takes priority as the nurse trends rhythm response to lidocaine?
options: Oxygen saturation trending 96% on 2 L/min nasal cannula
Occasional premature ventricular contractions that match baseline frequency
Complaint of mild metallic taste
A progressive drop in arterial blood pressure accompanied by bradycardia
Telemetry tracing that now shows a broadening QRS duration
Client reporting localized IV site warmth
questions.explanation: Hypotension with bradycardia suggests hemodynamic compromise from the infusion.

questions.text:
The nurse enters the room of a 74-year-old with acute decompensated heart failure (Mr. Alvarez) in a cardiac step-down unit to administer IV furosemide bolus every 4 hours. The client has lost 1.5 kg since admission and labs are pending.

Which assessment finding shows the diuretic is causing harm?
options: Client requests assistance to the bathroom every two hours
Sodium level of 134 mEq/L
Potassium level of 2.9 mEq/L
Net negative output of 1 liter over 8 hours
Lung sounds improved from coarse crackles to fine bibasilar crackles
Serum creatinine rising from 1.0 to 1.8 mg/dL overnight
questions.explanation: Severe hypokalemia predisposes the client to lethal arrhythmias.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 76-year-old with newly prescribed medications after hospitalization (Ms. Kowalski) in a transitional care clinic. The client is prescribed medication reconciliation. Home medications include anticoagulants, NSAIDs, and antiplatelets.

What adverse effect is most concerning with this medication combination?
options: Family helps manage medication administration
Client sees multiple specialists
Diphenhydramine prescribed for sleep in an 82-year-old
Client uses a weekly pill organizer
New cognitive impairment with urinary retention and dry mouth
Concurrent use of warfarin, aspirin, and ibuprofen
questions.explanation: Beers Criteria identifies antihistamines as potentially inappropriate for elderly due to anticholinergic effects.

questions.text:
The nurse reviews the medical record of a 35-year-old postpartum client with type 1 diabetes (Mr. Okoye) in a home-health visit. The client is prescribed insulin pump therapy. She has a low-grade fever and poor appetite.

Which statement shows correct understanding of sick-day insulin management?
options: Take double the usual correction bolus at bedtime
Check blood glucose and ketones every 3 to 4 hours
Avoid electrolyte drinks because they contain sodium
Hold all insulin doses until solid food resumes
Contact the provider for persistent fever or moderate ketones
Skip ketone testing if glucose stays under 180 mg/dL
questions.explanation: Frequent monitoring catches hypoglycemia or ketosis early during illness.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a cardiac step-down unit, the nurse checks on Mr. Carter, a 65-year-old post-cardiac catheterization with contrast dye, who is receiving IV hydration protocol. Urine output has decreased to 20 mL/hour over the past 4 hours.

Which laboratory finding is the earliest indicator of acute kidney injury?
options: Urine specific gravity of 1.010
Client reports nausea and fatigue
Urine output less than 0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6 consecutive hours
Serum creatinine increase of 0.3 mg/dL or more within 48 hours
BUN/creatinine ratio of 15:1
Potassium level of 6.2 mEq/L with peaked T waves on ECG
questions.explanation: Oliguria is a defining characteristic of AKI.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 70-year-old with ischemic cardiomyopathy and frequent PVCs (Ms. Chenoweth) in a medical ICU. The client is receiving lidocaine at 1.5 mg/min. The client reports new light-headedness after an hour of therapy.

Which cue needs the fastest intervention while titrating antiarrhythmic infusion?
options: A progressive drop in arterial blood pressure accompanied by bradycardia
Telemetry tracing that now shows a broadening QRS duration
Complaint of mild metallic taste
Client reporting localized IV site warmth
Occasional premature ventricular contractions that match baseline frequency
Oxygen saturation trending 96% on 2 L/min nasal cannula
questions.explanation: Hypotension with bradycardia suggests hemodynamic compromise from the infusion.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of post-op care protocols for post-operative clients requiring various interventions (Mx. Santos) in a surgical recovery unit, the nurse performs an assessment. Staffing is adequate with a mix of RNs, LPNs, and UAPs.

Which task can the RN safely delegate to unlicensed assistive personnel?
options: Apply non-sterile dressing to a chronic wound
Document intake and output measurements
Perform initial assessment on a newly admitted client
Obtain vital signs on a stable post-op client
Feed a client with dysphagia and aspiration risk
Report changes in client condition to the charge nurse
questions.explanation: Initial assessments require RN clinical judgment and cannot be delegated.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of a 28-year-old 30 minutes post-vaginal delivery (Mr. Alvarez) in a labor and delivery unit. The client's current regimen includes fundal massage and oxytocin infusion. The client delivered a 9-pound infant after prolonged labor.

Which assessment finding indicates postpartum hemorrhage?
options: Perform vigorous fundal massage while supporting the lower uterine segment
Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
Fundus firm at umbilicus level
Lochia rubra with small clots
Fundus boggy and displaced to the right above the umbilicus
Blood loss exceeding 500 mL vaginal or 1000 mL cesarean
questions.explanation: Stimulates uterine contraction to control bleeding from placental site.

questions.text:
A nurse in a medical unit is managing the care of Mr. Yang, a 52-year-old admitted with active pulmonary tuberculosis, who is undergoing multi-drug anti-tubercular regimen. Sputum cultures are positive for acid-fast bacilli.

What personal protective equipment must the nurse wear?
options: Wear a surgical mask, which is sufficient for TB
Cohort the client with another TB patient
Place the client in a negative pressure isolation room
Standard precautions alone are adequate
Keep the door closed at all times
Wear an N95 respirator before entering the room
questions.explanation: Airborne precautions require negative pressure to prevent organism spread.

questions.text:
A client, Mr. Rossi (a 38-year-old with MG admitted for pneumonia), asks the nurse in a medical ICU about their plasma exchange. Bulbar symptoms are worsening with dysphagia and weak cough.

What intervention should the nurse anticipate first?
options: Client reports feeling more fatigued than usual
Prepare for intubation with declining respiratory effort
Recent antibiotic therapy with fluoroquinolone
Ptosis, diplopia, and dysphagia with normal pupil size
Muscle strength improves temporarily after edrophonium administration
Administer atropine if cholinergic crisis is confirmed
questions.explanation: Both crisis types can cause respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 45-year-old on day 2 of chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma (Ms. Gomez) in a cancer center. Current therapy includes rasburicase administration. Urine output has been adequate at 150 mL/hour.

Which client is at highest risk for this complication?
options: Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
Potassium 6.8 mEq/L, phosphorus 7.2 mg/dL, calcium 6.9 mg/dL
Cardiac monitor showing peaked T waves and widened QRS
Urine pH of 6.5
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
questions.explanation: Severe hyperuricemia can cause acute kidney injury from crystal deposition.

questions.text:
A nurse in an emergency department is managing the care of Mx. Jordan, a 28-year-old with sickle cell disease reporting severe chest and back pain, who is undergoing IV opioid analgesia and hydration. Pain started 6 hours ago and rates it 9/10.

Which intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: Encourage bed rest to conserve energy
Initiate aggressive pain management with opioids around-the-clock
Hemoglobin of 8 g/dL
New onset fever, chest pain, and decreased oxygen saturation
Administer IV fluids at 1.5 times maintenance to promote hemodilution
Client requests heating pad for painful joints
questions.explanation: Adequate analgesia is essential; use scheduled dosing rather than PRN only.

questions.text:
A client, Mr. Yang (a 38-year-old with MG admitted for pneumonia), asks the nurse in a medical ICU about their plasma exchange. Bulbar symptoms are worsening with dysphagia and weak cough.

Which medication change likely precipitated this crisis?
options: Prepare for intubation with declining respiratory effort
Administer atropine if cholinergic crisis is confirmed
Muscle strength improves temporarily after edrophonium administration
Recent antibiotic therapy with fluoroquinolone
Ptosis, diplopia, and dysphagia with normal pupil size
Client reports feeling more fatigued than usual
questions.explanation: Both crisis types can cause respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

questions.text:
The healthcare provider prescribes IV regular insulin and potassium replacement for a 24-year-old admitted for DKA now on hour 8 of treatment (Ms. Yamamoto) in a medical ICU. Glucose has dropped to 180 mg/dL but pH remains 7.28.

Which complication requires immediate recognition during treatment?
options: Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
Initiate 0.9% normal saline bolus before starting insulin
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
Add potassium to IV fluids once level drops below 5.3 mEq/L
Client reports extreme thirst
questions.explanation: Closure of anion gap indicates resolution of ketoacidosis.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Ms. Gomez, a 68-year-old post-op day 3 from bowel resection in a surgical ICU, who is currently on vasopressor support. Blood cultures are pending and lactate is 4.2 mmol/L.

Which assessment finding is the earliest indicator of septic shock?
options: Temperature of 101.8°F (38.8°C)
Mean arterial pressure drops below 65 mm Hg despite fluids
Urine output of 35 mL/hour after fluid bolus
Obtain blood cultures before initiating antibiotics
Administer 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus within the first 3 hours
White blood cell count of 18,000/mm³
questions.explanation: Persistent hypotension after fluid resuscitation requires vasopressors.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in an orthopedic unit, the nurse checks on Mr. Haddad, an 82-year-old post-op day 2 from hip replacement with sudden confusion, who is receiving pain management and antibiotics. Family reports the client was oriented and independent before surgery.

Which factor is most likely contributing to the acute confusion?
options: Recent addition of multiple new medications including opioids and anticholinergics
Acute onset of confusion with fluctuating level of consciousness
Client cannot recall short-term events
Gradual cognitive decline over several years
Family requests pharmacologic sedation
Investigate for underlying infection, hypoxia, or metabolic disturbance
questions.explanation: Polypharmacy, especially with high-risk meds, commonly triggers delirium.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 55-year-old with head injury and impaired swallowing (Mr. Wallace) in a rehabilitation unit. The client is receiving bolus tube feedings four times daily. The client develops sudden coughing and respiratory distress during feeding.

What action should the nurse take before initiating tube feeding?
options: Maintain head of bed elevation at least 30-45 degrees during and after feeding
Client reports feeling bloated
Sudden respiratory distress with diminished breath sounds
Verify tube placement by checking pH of aspirate and comparing to X-ray
Flush the tube with 30 mL water before and after feeding
Gastric residual of 75 mL
questions.explanation: Positioning reduces aspiration risk significantly.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of routine prenatal care for a 28-year-old at a prenatal visit appearing anxious and withdrawn (Mr. Okoye) in an outpatient obstetric clinic, the nurse performs an assessment. The client minimizes injuries and partner controls all conversation.

Which assessment finding raises concern for intimate partner violence?
options: Interview the client privately without the partner present
Injuries in various stages of healing with inconsistent explanations
Provide information about domestic violence resources and safety planning
Delay in seeking treatment after injury
Partner appears concerned and attentive
Client denies abuse when partner is present
questions.explanation: Mandatory for accurate assessment and to provide opportunity for disclosure.

questions.text:
In a medical unit, the nurse is evaluating a 35-year-old receiving IV antibiotics who suddenly develops hives and throat tightness (Ms. Wilson) who is receiving epinephrine administration. The infusion was started 10 minutes ago.

Which intervention should the nurse implement immediately?
options: Blood pressure 82/50 mm Hg with rapid, weak pulse
Stop the infusion and maintain IV access with normal saline
Administer diphenhydramine 50 mg IV after epinephrine
Client reports feeling anxious and dizzy
Urticaria spreading across the chest and arms
Administer epinephrine 0.3-0.5 mg IM into the lateral thigh immediately
questions.explanation: Distributive shock from massive vasodilation requires immediate treatment.

questions.text:
In an outpatient obstetric clinic, the nurse is evaluating a 28-year-old at a prenatal visit appearing anxious and withdrawn (Ms. Patel) who is receiving routine prenatal care. The client minimizes injuries and partner controls all conversation.

Which assessment finding raises concern for intimate partner violence?
options: Partner appears concerned and attentive
Client denies abuse when partner is present
Interview the client privately without the partner present
Document findings objectively using body maps and photographs with consent
Injuries in various stages of healing with inconsistent explanations
Delay in seeking treatment after injury
questions.explanation: Mandatory for accurate assessment and to provide opportunity for disclosure.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old with type 1 diabetes presenting with Kussmaul respirations (Ms. Silva) is being treated in an emergency department with insulin infusion protocol. Blood glucose is 520 mg/dL with pH 7.18 and positive ketones.

Which intervention should the nurse implement first?
options: New onset headache, bradycardia, and altered mental status
Client reports extreme thirst
Blood glucose of 180 mg/dL after 6 hours of treatment
Anion gap closed with bicarbonate above 18 mEq/L
Continue insulin infusion until anion gap closes, not just until glucose normalizes
Initiate 0.9% normal saline bolus before starting insulin
questions.explanation: Signs of cerebral edema, a life-threatening complication of DKA treatment.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 68-year-old scheduled for cardiac catheterization in one hour (Mr. Yang) in a pre-procedure area. Current therapy includes informed consent process. The client signed the consent form but asks basic questions about the procedure.

Which action protects the client's rights?
options: Client appears nervous about the procedure
Client states, 'I don't want the procedure, but my family insists'
Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Family members are present and supportive
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
questions.explanation: Coercion invalidates consent; client autonomy must be respected.

questions.text:
The nurse is assigned to a 17-year-old admitted for major depressive disorder (Ms. Okafor) in an inpatient behavioral health unit. Current therapy includes SSRIs and cognitive behavioral therapy. The client is on 15-minute checks.

Which statement requires the fastest action?
options: Client sleeps six hours overnight
Client attends all therapy groups and participates
Client refuses to contract for safety after disclosing a lethal plan
Client journals feelings during group therapy
Client requests extra art supplies for distraction
Client hoards medications instead of taking them
questions.explanation: Refusal indicates the plan is active and requires continuous observation.

questions.text:
The nurse is planning discharge teaching for a 28-year-old at a prenatal visit appearing anxious and withdrawn (Mr. Singh) in an outpatient obstetric clinic regarding routine prenatal care. The client minimizes injuries and partner controls all conversation.

Which assessment finding raises concern for intimate partner violence?
options: Partner appears concerned and attentive
Client denies abuse when partner is present
Document findings objectively using body maps and photographs with consent
Provide information about domestic violence resources and safety planning
Injuries in various stages of healing with inconsistent explanations
Delay in seeking treatment after injury
questions.explanation: Thorough documentation supports legal proceedings and continuity of care.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old trauma patient (Mr. Al-Rashid) is being treated in an emergency department bay with large-bore IV for potential transfusion. Hair covers the antecubital region and needs quick management.

What is the safest way to manage excess hair before starting the IV?
options: Use a sterile scalpel to remove hair close to the skin
Shave the area with a razor just before insertion
Leave the hair intact to avoid upsetting the client
Use a single-patient clipper to trim hair down to stubble
Smooth the hair with a water-based lubricant before taping
Apply depilatory cream and wipe it off after three minutes
questions.explanation: Clipping removes hair without causing micro-abrasions that raise infection risk.

questions.text:
A client, Mr. Rossi (a 28-year-old recently started on clozapine), asks the nurse in a mental health treatment facility about their atypical antipsychotic with weekly monitoring. The client develops fever, confusion, and muscle rigidity.

Which adverse effect requires immediate intervention?
options: Temperature 104°F (40°C) with severe muscle rigidity and altered mental status
Involuntary tongue protrusion and facial grimacing
Mild hand tremor noted during medication administration
Teach client to report fever, sore throat, or flu-like symptoms immediately
Client reports feeling drowsy in the afternoon
Weight gain of 5 pounds over 2 months
questions.explanation: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening emergency requiring immediate discontinuation.

questions.text:
At the beginning of the shift in a home-health visit, the nurse checks on Ms. Nguyen, a 35-year-old postpartum client with type 1 diabetes, who is receiving insulin pump therapy. She has a low-grade fever and poor appetite.

Which statement shows correct understanding of sick-day insulin management?
options: Sip 8 to 12 ounces of carb-containing fluids each hour
Skip ketone testing if glucose stays under 180 mg/dL
Hold all insulin doses until solid food resumes
Avoid electrolyte drinks because they contain sodium
Check blood glucose and ketones every 3 to 4 hours
Take double the usual correction bolus at bedtime
questions.explanation: Carbohydrates prevent starvation ketosis when solid food is not tolerated.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mr. Ibrahim, a 28-year-old 30 minutes post-vaginal delivery in a labor and delivery unit who is receiving fundal massage and oxytocin infusion. The client delivered a 9-pound infant after prolonged labor.

Which assessment finding indicates postpartum hemorrhage?
options: Rapid pulse, decreased blood pressure, and restlessness
Lochia rubra with small clots
Blood loss exceeding 500 mL vaginal or 1000 mL cesarean
Client reports feeling weak and thirsty
Perform vigorous fundal massage while supporting the lower uterine segment
Fundus firm at umbilicus level
questions.explanation: Signs of hypovolemic shock requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of nebulized beta-agonists and steroids for a 4-year-old with asthma exacerbation (Mr. Kaur) in an emergency department, the nurse performs an assessment. The child has been receiving back-to-back treatments.

Which assessment requires immediate intervention?
options: Pulse oximetry falling to 88% despite oxygen support
Heart rate 160/min while crying
Capillary refill under 2 seconds
Mild inspiratory wheezing improving after treatment
Suprasternal and intercostal retractions that suddenly diminish
Respiratory rate of 34/min with even chest rise
questions.explanation: Persistent hypoxemia warrants escalation.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Mx. Jordan, a 45-year-old on day 2 of chemotherapy for Burkitt lymphoma in a cancer center, who is currently on rasburicase administration. Urine output has been adequate at 150 mL/hour.

Which client is at highest risk for this complication?
options: Urine pH of 6.5
Maintain urine output of at least 2-3 L/day with IV hydration
Uric acid level of 12 mg/dL with decreased urine output
Client reports muscle cramps and tingling
Cardiac monitor showing peaked T waves and widened QRS
LDH elevated at twice the upper limit of normal
questions.explanation: High urine flow prevents crystal formation and flushes metabolites.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 55-year-old with suspected urosepsis (Ms. Kowalski) in an emergency department. The client is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics and IV fluid bolus. The client arrived with fever, confusion, and hypotension.

Which laboratory value best indicates adequate resuscitation?
options: White blood cell count of 18,000/mm³
Temperature of 101.8°F (38.8°C)
Mean arterial pressure drops below 65 mm Hg despite fluids
Urine output of 35 mL/hour after fluid bolus
Lactate level trending down from 4.2 to 2.1 mmol/L
Obtain blood cultures before initiating antibiotics
questions.explanation: Persistent hypotension after fluid resuscitation requires vasopressors.

questions.text:
The nurse is caring for a 32-year-old post-central line insertion with sudden dyspnea (Mx. Santos) in a medical ICU. The client is receiving supplemental oxygen. The client received a subclavian line 30 minutes ago.

Which client is at highest risk for this complication?
options: Absent breath sounds with hyperresonance to percussion on one side
Subcutaneous emphysema palpable at the insertion site
Chest X-ray confirmation before treatment
Tracheal deviation away from the affected side with severe dyspnea
Hypotension, distended neck veins, and rapid deterioration
Unilateral chest pain worsening with deep breathing
questions.explanation: Classic findings of pneumothorax; hyperresonance indicates air-filled space.

questions.text:
During shift report, the nurse receives information about Mr. Park, a 68-year-old recovering from a mechanical mitral valve replacement in a cardiac step-down unit who is receiving warfarin with bridge therapy. The client takes herbal supplements at home and prepares leafy greens daily.

What teaching point has the highest priority while reinforcing home safety on anticoagulants?
options: Keep vitamin K intake consistent rather than eliminating leafy vegetables
Take the medication at bedtime to avoid daytime drowsiness
Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
Keep a blood pressure log every morning
Use ibuprofen for headaches instead of acetaminophen
Inform every healthcare provider and dentist about warfarin therapy
questions.explanation: Stable vitamin K consumption prevents sudden INR shifts.

questions.text:
In an emergency department, the nurse is evaluating a 4-year-old with asthma exacerbation (Mr. Al-Rashid) who is receiving nebulized beta-agonists and steroids. The child has been receiving back-to-back treatments.

Which assessment requires immediate intervention?
options: Heart rate 160/min while crying
Grunting with each exhalation
Respiratory rate of 34/min with even chest rise
Capillary refill under 2 seconds
Mild inspiratory wheezing improving after treatment
Pulse oximetry falling to 88% despite oxygen support
questions.explanation: Grunting indicates the child is trying to maintain airway pressure.

questions.text:
A client, Mr. Ibrahim (a 25-year-old with family history of anesthesia complications), asks the nurse in a surgical suite about their emergency protocol activation. End-tidal CO2 is rapidly rising with muscle rigidity noted.

What is the priority intervention?
options: Initiate active cooling measures
Prepare dantrolene sodium for immediate IV administration
Discontinue all triggering agents and hyperventilate with 100% oxygen
Family history of unexplained perioperative death
Obtain arterial blood gas to assess metabolic acidosis
Temperature spiking to 105°F (40.6°C) or higher
questions.explanation: Dantrolene is the specific antidote and must be given immediately.

questions.text:
While assessing a 30-year-old at 33 weeks' gestation with severe preeclampsia (Mr. Carter) in a labor and delivery suite, the nurse notes the client is receiving magnesium sulfate at 2 g/hour. The nurse performs hourly assessments while antihypertensives run concurrently.

Which assessment should prompt the nurse to stop the infusion and follow the emergency protocol?
options: Magnesium level reported at 5.5 mg/dL
Client describes mild nausea
Absent patellar reflexes noted on exam
Client reports feeling warm and flushed
Blood pressure decreases from 158/102 to 146/94
Serum magnesium level of 9.0 mg/dL
questions.explanation: Loss of deep tendon reflexes precedes respiratory collapse and mandates stopping the infusion.

questions.text:
The nurse assumes care of a 45-year-old with a hemorrhagic stroke (Ms. Kowalski) in a neuro step-down unit. The client's current regimen includes hyperosmolar therapy. The nurse performs hourly cranial nerve checks.

Which cue should prompt the nurse to prepare for rapid intervention?
options: Decorticate posturing noted during stimulation
Urine output of 55 mL/hour
ICP waveform showing regular P1>P2 pattern
Temperature of 99.2 F (37.3 C)
Widening pulse pressure with bradycardia
Client reports headache rated 4/10
questions.explanation: Posturing signifies significant neurologic deterioration.

questions.text:
Following the initiation of interpreter services for a 45-year-old with limited English proficiency signing surgical consent (Mr. Lopez) in a surgical holding area, the nurse performs an assessment. The consent form is in English and no interpreter was present.

What indicates the consent is not valid?
options: Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Client appears nervous about the procedure
Family members are present and supportive
Client asks, 'What exactly are they going to do during this test?'
Client states, 'I don't want the procedure, but my family insists'
questions.explanation: Nurse advocates by ensuring informed consent requirements are met.

questions.text:
An interdisciplinary team in a psychiatric outpatient clinic is discussing the care plan for Mr. Yang, a 34-year-old with schizophrenia taking haloperidol, who is receiving typical antipsychotic medication. The client reports new muscle stiffness and difficulty swallowing.

Which teaching point is most important for this medication?
options: Mild hand tremor noted during medication administration
Teach client to report fever, sore throat, or flu-like symptoms immediately
Temperature 104°F (40°C) with severe muscle rigidity and altered mental status
White blood cell count of 2,000/mm³ with neutropenia
Weight gain of 5 pounds over 2 months
Client reports feeling drowsy in the afternoon
questions.explanation: Early signs of agranulocytosis require urgent medical evaluation.

questions.text:
The nurse is preparing to assess Ms. Wilson, a 26-year-old with postpartum hypertension in a high-risk obstetric unit, who is currently on magnesium sulfate infusion. Deep tendon reflexes and respiratory status are trending every 30 minutes.

Which cue signals magnesium sulfate toxicity?
options: Client describes mild nausea
Absent patellar reflexes noted on exam
Magnesium level reported at 5.5 mg/dL
Serum magnesium level of 9.0 mg/dL
Blood pressure decreases from 158/102 to 146/94
Client reports feeling warm and flushed
questions.explanation: Loss of deep tendon reflexes precedes respiratory collapse and mandates stopping the infusion.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor (Ms. Mbatha) is being treated in a labor and delivery suite with continuous external fetal monitoring. Contractions are occurring every 3 minutes lasting 60 seconds.

Which fetal heart rate pattern requires immediate intervention?
options: Prolonged deceleration lasting 4 minutes with baseline below 90 bpm
Recurrent late decelerations with minimal variability
Early decelerations that mirror contraction pattern
Absent variability with recurrent variable decelerations
Moderate variability with accelerations during fetal movement
Baseline fetal heart rate of 145 bpm
questions.explanation: Prolonged bradycardia suggests cord compression or placental abruption.

questions.text:
Electronic health records for Ms. Chenoweth, a 68-year-old scheduled for cardiac catheterization in one hour in a pre-procedure area, indicate active treatment with informed consent process. The client signed the consent form but asks basic questions about the procedure.

Which situation requires the nurse to intervene before the procedure?
options: Witness the client's signature on the consent form
Notify the physician that the client needs clarification before proceeding
Client states, 'I don't want the procedure, but my family insists'
Client appears nervous about the procedure
Consent signed while client was under influence of sedative medications
Family members are present and supportive
questions.explanation: Nurse advocates by ensuring informed consent requirements are met.
